Photocatalyst has been of considerable interest due to its new technology for environmental pollution. Among the photocatalyst semiconductors, titanium dioxide is known as a photocatalyst for the removal of environmental contaminants. In this research, we first designed a new self-made laboratory photocatalytic reactor and then photocatalytic properties of TiO2 nanoparticles are studied by using UV-A light and photodegradation of methylene blue as a water pollutant evaluated until the photocatalytic process optimizes with the process parameters. The parameters that were examined include: initial dye concentration, the mass of TiO2 nanoparticle, pH value, and TiO2 nano-sized particles. Absorbance spectra were measured using a spectrophotometer and the concentration of the test solution was calculated by using the Beer-Lambert Law. Our test results showed that the photocatalytic UV-A/TiO2 nanoparticle is a promising method for treating wastewater. The most important part is that with reduction of TiO2 particles from nano to micro scale, photodegradation time becomes very slowly and even did not reach to zero after 5 h. Also, photocatayst reaction efficency for 10 nm TiO2 nanoparticles improves to 90% within one hour and photodegradation completed after two hour, it means that the photocatalyst activity increases with increasing surface area.

. Introduction
The greatest chemical materials group produced in the world is textile and painting industries. During production and sage of them, many contaminations enter to the environment [1]. Thus, textile and painting industries’ pollutions are a ain source of the environmental organic contaminations, so degradation and conversion of them into harmless mineral ompounds is an important issue. On the other hand, textile and paining industries are the most consuming of water. At esult, in these industries plenty of wastewater is produced during various production processes. If wastewater without urification enters to the environment, it can be affect water ecosystem with many different methods. Indeed, painting and ts decomposition could be a major threat for the environment [2,3]. Therefore, purification of wastewater is very necessary efore it is discharged to the environment.
Many physical and chemical methods are used for this purpose that most important of them is including; reverse osmosis, dsorption, precipitate, and coalescence. These methods only transfer pollution from a phase to another phase and concenrate them and also are non-destructive processes. In recent years, advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) as a substitution are

used for regular purification. In these processes, unstable radicals high reaction specially free hydroxyl radicals are used for degradation of pollutant and conversion to harmless mineral materials such as; carbon dioxide, water, and mineral salts [4]. Decomposition of the color photocatalyst by using titanium dioxide catalyst accompany with UV beam is among AOPs that its usage is going to extend [5]. Up to now, different materials such as; GaAs, PbS, CdS, Fe2O3, SnO2, WO3, ZnO, TiO2, and their composites has been used as photocatalyst for degradation of pollutant. Main parameter for a semiconductor photocatalyst is that reduction of potential charge couple i.e. h+/e− can be located within photocatalyst energy gap range. Lowest level of conduction band determines reduction ability of photoelectrons while highest level of valence band determines reduction ability of produced holes by light. In addition to suitable energy gap for a semiconductor, it must be easy to produce and application and low cost and to be harmless for human and environment and effectively activated by sun light and able to catalyze effectively any reactions.
Most of reported photocatalyst such as GaAs, PbS, and CdS have limitations like toxic and also are not stable suitably for catalyze in aqueous media since they become corrosion under light. ZnO is not stable since dissolved easily in water and Zn(OH)2 produces on the surface of ZnO which makes passivate catalyst with time. Fe2O3, SnO2, and WO3 have conduction band edge at lower energy than reversible hydrogen potential. Therefore systems which are used these materials, need an external electrical bias for completion of water reaction and hydrogen evolution at cathode. However, TiO2 is close to an ideal photocatalyst and is a criterion for utility of other photocatalysts. Among photocatalysts, TiO2 has got much attentions due to extensive properties such as chemical and optical stability, low cost, dissolvable in water, harmless, do not need high energy, high efficiency, and do not produce pollution. Also depends on application, its holes can be highly oxidizing and reducing [5]. Titanium dioxide nanoparticles are used as a photocatalyst in two methods; constant phase and solution phase that both methods have their own advantages. However, solution phase is declined more pollutant concentrations than constant phase but since titanium dioxide remains after purification of waste, it should separate from the solution [6]. Methylene blue (MB) is a color cationic and is used as a traditional dye for painting cotton, wool, and silk. Its smelling may cause breathe hazards and its direct contact may create dangers damages to human eyes, local burning, nausea, vomiting, hyperhidrosis, and mental disorders [7,8].
In this research, UV-A/TiO2 nanoparticle device was fabricated for photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue. The photocatalytic behavior of the device was studied under various conditions such as; initial dye concentration, the mass of TiO2 nanoparticle, pH value, and TiO2 nano-sized particles. Also, we have measured number of broken MB molecules for all above various conditions which is not reported so far. Nano-sized TiO2 particles show significant different with the bulk TiO2 in many aspects due to quantum confinement effect. The reason could be due to increasing surface area with decreasing particle size.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental details
sections.text:
TiO2 powder was obtained from Merck with a crystal structure of anatase, particle size of 200 nm, and molecular weight of 79.90 g/mol. Methylene blue was bought from Merck with molecular weight of 319.85 g/mol. Masses of TiO2 powder and MB were measured by digital balance Model GR200 with accuracy of 0.1 mg.
In addition to TiO2 powder, we have used following three TiO2 pastes for study of TiO2 nano-sized particles;
1. Colloidal solution of TiO2 nanoparticles with sizes less than 10 nm was bought from Sharif Solar Co. with SolT10A:Amorphous Aqueous TiO2 sol code. 2. Colloidal solution of TiO2 nanoparticles with a crystal structure of anatase and particle size of 30 nm was bought from Sharif Solar Co. with Sol-T30C:Crystalline Aqueous TiO2 sol code. 3. TiO2 paste with a crystal structure of anatase and particle size of 20 nm was bought from Sharif Solar Co. with PST20T:Transparent TiO2 paste code.
pH calibration was done by %38 hydrochloric acid and %35.4 sodium hydroxide. A self-made photocatalyst reactor was designed and made from glass with volume of 650 mL. During experiment the reactor was covered with Al foil and kept in dark box to protect dispersion of UV light. Besides, all the experimental tests are performed in room temperature. Fig. 1 shows schematic view of the reactor.

In each experiment, a desired value of MB was inserted into distilled water under very mild stirring for 10 min to comlete the mixing. Following the addition of a desired value TiO2 powder, this mixture was stirred continuously at room emperature. In each experiment, every 2 mL of the solution were taken in an equal time interval of 30 min and inserted into entrifuge for 15 min to separate the TiO2 nanoparticles from the dye solution. The dye concentration was determined by aking the UV absorption spectra using an Optics Oceans spectrophotometer, HR4000 UV-VIS-NIR Model in the wavelength ange of 200–1100 nm. The highest absorbance at 664 nm was recorded for MB.
. Results and discussion
.1. Light performance
We have used a UV array to make the photocatalytic degradation device. The UV array was two 9 V UV-A lamps. Fig. 2 hows the wavelength spectrum of the UV lamp at room temperature. The emission wavelength of the UV is 364 nm and the ight power is 30 Lx. This monochromatic light source causes no thermal damage or potentially harmful deep UV effects to bjects when they are irradiated. Its low power consumption makes it as an ideal, energy-saving, and environment-friendly ight source.
.2. Structural and morphological analysis
Fig. 3 shows SEM image of TiO2 particles. By using SEM image and Digimizer software, mean size of particles were btained about 200 nm. Fig. 4 shows XRD pattern of TiO2 particles which confirms anatase crystal structure.
.3. UV–vis test of methylene blue
The experiment was done at different concentration of MB (5, 10, 15, 20 mg/L), 1 g TiO2 powder weight with 200 nm article size, neutral initial pH, and in an equal time interval. Fig. 5 shows absorbance spectrum versus wavelength for ethylene blue with concentration of 20 mg/L at different time intervals. According to absorbance spectrum of samples,
maximum absorbance of all samples occurs at 660 nm wavelength. First absorbance spectrum was taken at zero time (i.e. before illumination UV light and TiO2 catalyst) and peak has highest value. After illumination starts every an hour, absorbance spectrum were recorded and showed that peak value reduces moderately. This shows that during experiment absorbance value decrease with exposure to time and finally after 9 h absorbance peak become nearly smooth while solution blue color also become color less with passing time.
Fig. 6 shows the chemical structure of Methylene blue and the photocatalytic reaction pathway. N-dealkylation of dyes containing auxochromic alkylamine groups plays an important role in photocatalytic degradation. The color of Methylene blue solutions becomes weaker when part of the methyl groups degrade, and hypochromic shift occurs. Hence, N-demethylation of Methylene blue occurs as described in the pathway at first, and finally Methylene blue depredated into H2O, CO2, and other inorganic molecules [9].

In this research, determination of concentration at absorption maximum wavelength by the Beer-Lambert Law was alculated. Fig. 7 depict that the decomposition of MB decreased with increasing initial dye concentrations of the dye from 5 o 20 mg/L. The UV light can be made to go more easily through the solution to irradiate the TiO2 when the initial dye oncentration is lower, therefore, photonic efficiency increased with decreasing initial dye concentration. sections.heading: 3.6. The effect of the mass of TiO2
sections.text:
The experiment was done at different weights of TiO2 (0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1 g), intial dye concentartion of 10 mg/L, netural intial pH, and constant time interval. Fig. 9 shows the effect of the mass of TiO2 on photodegradation by UV-A/TiO2 process during five hours.
As indicated in Fig. 9, when TiO2 was added in the device, photodegradation capability of the device increased because TiO2 has a good photocatalytic performance and also production of free electrons in conduction band increases with increasing catalyst dose and irradiation time which is agreed with others [12,15]. However, when more TiO2 is added, solution becomes more turbid, and the UV light becomes hard to go through the water. Large quantities of TiO2 could not be irradiated by our UV light, and so the photonic efficiency of TiO2 is decreased with a large quantity of TiO2 [16].
Table 2 shows MB photodegradation rate by using slope of curves in Fig. 9 at time interval of one hour. This result showed that photodegradation rate at initial process hours is higher and by passing time photodegradation occurs at lower velocity.

.8. The effect of TiO2 particle size
The experiment was done at different nanoparticle sizes of TiO2 (10, 20, 30, and 200 nm), 0.5 g photocatalyst, MB oncentration of 10 mg/L, neutral initial pH, and constant time interval. Fig. 13 shows the effect of the size of TiO2 on hotodegradation by the UV-A/TiO2 process during five hours.
The most important point is when TiO2 particles goes from nano scale to micro scale, photodegradation becomes very lowly and even for particle size of 200 nm after five hours did not reach to zero. Indeed, surface area has a major role or photocatalyst and by increasing surface area, photocatalyst activity increases. The increase of surface area is due to eduction of nanoparticle size. This increase can prepare increasing contact surface between photocatalyst and goal material. t a photocatalyst system, molecular light induction occurs at photocatalyst surface, thus higher efficiency of photocatalyst eaction could be due to increasing surface area of photocatalyst.
Table 4 shows MB photodegradation rate by using slope of curves in Fig. 13 at time interval of one hour. This result howed that photodegradation rate at initial process hours is higher and by passing time, photodegradation occurs at lower elocity. The reason could be due to fabrication of middle products which react with hydroxyl radicals then by passing time nd increasing middle products concentrations in one hand and decreasing existing MB value in the solution on the other and, noticeable value of formed radicals are applying for degradation of middle products to simple products [17]. At result, B photodegradation rate or reaction velocity reduces by passing time. Fig. 14 shows number of broken MB molecules at different particle sizes of TiO2 for various times after photocatalyst rocess. The figure indicate that for all samples by passing time, more amount of MB molecules bonds are broken but at amples which have used smaller nanoparticles of TiO2 for all times, broken of MB molecules bonds and reduction of molecule umbers are increased. The reason is that at photocatalyst process electron-hole recombination can reduce photocatalyst ctivity but if particle size reduces, the distance which fabricated electrons and holes need with photon to reach surface eaction sites reduces and at result probability of electron-hole recombination reduces. On the other hand, surface area ncreases with reduction of TiO2 photocatalyst particle size which causes higher contact of pollutant with photocatalyst and
then photodegradation increases. In general, reduction of particle size causes reduction of electron-hole recombination and enhancement of surface area which can improve photocatalyst reaction efficiency.
Electron-hole pair before entering to photocatalyst process recombined and reduces photocatalyst efficiency. Electronhole recombination occurs on surface or volume of photocatalyst and generates heat. When electron-hole recombination occurs that time of this recombination is lower than time for penetrating charge on photocatalyst surface. By using absorption spectroscopy time of trapping and charge recombination in semiconductors are in the order of femto and pico seconds. Time of electron trapping for TiO2 is about 2–200 fs and life time for electron-hole pair is about 30 ns. These times depends of type of semiconductor and its size. Indeed, with decreasing particle size up to 10 nm, electron-hole recombination rate reduces since charge carrier motion on photocatalyst is done fast. However, other parameters such as impurities and defects in lattice which are factor of trapping are exist and affects electron-hole recombination rate [19]. It should mention that some data shows opposite process. The reason could be due to number of defects on surface. Then it should find suitable methods to synthesize particles. Then, particles size reduces and can get high quality particles. One of the parameters which affect TiO2 photocatalyst activity is particle size. TiO2 photocatalyst activity increases with decreasing particle size up to 10 nm but with decreasing further, photocatalyst activity decreases. With deceasing particle size, distance for charge carrier penetration decreases. Indeed, photocatalyst reactions on photocatalyst surface increases. Therefore, the suitable size for photocatalyst particle is that quantum confinement effect takes place and ratio of surface to volume increases [20].

As a point of clarification it should be noted that most industrial wastewater treatment plants use chemical oxygen emand (COD) or total organic carbon (TOC) rather than biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) test. Due to the length of time equired to complete the BOD test (five days), BOD results provide historical data and do not facilitate rapid water quality ssessment for optimal process control. The highly variable chemical composition and strength of industrial wastewater equires a much more rapid method for measuring he organic concentration, hence the use of two hour COD test or 30 min OC analysis. Although TOC test can take 30 min to complete, but information obtained from a TOC analysis is less useful than nformation obtained from the other analysis. TOC test does not differentiate between compounds with the same number f carbon atoms in different stages of oxidation and will thus produce different oxygen demand results.
In this research, we introduced a method named UV-A/TiO2 nanoparticle device. Our test results can also be used to stimate the BOD results for a given sample, but required time to complete is two hour for 10 nm TiO2 nanoparticle size hich is comparable with COD test.
. Conclusions
We have studied the possibility of using the available UV-A/TiO2 device suitable for wastewater photodegradation. The ecomposition of MB in aqueous solutions by TiO2 photocatalyst processes with the UV-A was found to be technically easible under adequate and proper experimental conditions. In general, the most important issue of our work devoted to nvestigation of nanoparticle size effect at various sizes. The work is very interesting in recent years due to the development f new nano-materials. Also, we could improve the photocatalyst reaction efficiency to 90% within one hour for 10 nm TiO2 anoparticles.

metadata.abstractText: Photocatalyst has been of considerable interest due to its new technology for environmental pollution. Among the photocatalyst semiconductors, titanium dioxide is known as a photocatalyst for the removal of environmental contaminants. In this research, we first designed a new self-made laboratory photocatalytic reactor and then photocatalytic properties of TiO2 nanoparticles are studied by using UV-A light and photodegradation of methylene blue as a water pollutant evaluated until the photocatalytic process optimizes with the process parameters. The parameters that were examined include: initial dye concentration, the mass of TiO2 nanoparticle, pH value, and TiO2 nano-sized particles. Absorbance spectra were measured using a spectrophotometer and the concentration of the test solution was calculated by using the Beer-Lambert Law. Our test results showed that the photocatalytic UV-A/TiO2 nanoparticle is a promising method for treating wastewater. The most important part is that with reduction of TiO2 particles from nano to micro scale, photodegradation time becomes very slowly and even did not reach to zero after 5 h. Also, photocatayst reaction efficency for 10 nm TiO2 nanoparticles improves to 90% within one hour and photodegradation completed after two hour, it means that the photocatalyst activity increases with increasing surface area. © 2016 Elsevier GmbH.
